slides.title: Introduction to Error Spotting
slides.content:
Error Spotting, also known as Error Detection, is an important topic in English language exams like SSC GD. In this type of question, you are given a sentence divided into parts (usually 4-5 parts), and you need to identify which part contains a grammatical error. If there is no error, you select 'No Error'.

Error Spotting tests your understanding of:
- Grammar rules
- Sentence structure
- Subject-Verb agreement
- Tense usage
- Articles and prepositions
- Commonly confused words
- Idioms and phrases

This chapter will help you identify common errors and improve your grammar accuracy. The key to mastering error spotting is regular practice and understanding of grammar fundamentals.

slides.title: Subject-Verb Agreement Errors
slides.content:
Subject-Verb agreement means that the verb must agree with the subject in number (singular/plural) and person (first/second/third).

**Common Errors:**

**1. Singular subject with plural verb (or vice versa):**
❌ The team are playing well.
✓ The team is playing well. (Collective noun - singular)

❌ Each of the students have submitted their assignments.
✓ Each of the students has submitted their assignments. ('Each' is singular)

**2. Compound subjects:**
❌ Ram and Shyam is going to the market.
✓ Ram and Shyam are going to the market. (Two subjects - plural)

**3. Indefinite pronouns:**
❌ Everyone were present.
✓ Everyone was present. (Everyone is singular)

Singular: each, every, everyone, everybody, someone, somebody, anyone, anybody, no one, nobody, either, neither
Plural: both, few, many, several

**4. With 'of' phrases:**
❌ One of my friends are coming.
✓ One of my friends is coming. (Subject is 'one', not 'friends')

**5. Either-or, Neither-nor:**
Verb agrees with the nearer subject.
❌ Neither the students nor the teacher were ready.
✓ Neither the students nor the teacher was ready.
✓ Neither the teacher nor the students were ready.

question.text: Each of the boys / have completed / their homework / on time. / No Error
question.explanation:
Error is in part (B): 'have completed'

The subject 'Each' is singular, so it should take a singular verb 'has', not 'have'.

Correct sentence: Each of the boys has completed their homework on time.

'Each', 'every', 'either', 'neither' are always singular and take singular verbs.

slides.title: Tense Errors
slides.content:
Tense errors occur when the wrong form of verb is used for the time context.

**Common Tense Errors:**

**1. Mixing tenses unnecessarily:**
❌ He went to the market and buys vegetables.
✓ He went to the market and bought vegetables. (Both past)

**2. Wrong tense with time expressions:**
❌ Since morning, he is working.
✓ Since morning, he has been working. (Use Present Perfect Continuous with 'since')

❌ I am living here for 5 years.
✓ I have been living here for 5 years. (Use Present Perfect with duration)

**3. Conditional sentences:**
❌ If I will see him, I will tell him.
✓ If I see him, I will tell him. (Present tense in 'if' clause)

**4. Universal truths:**
❌ Teacher said that the earth moved around the sun.
✓ Teacher said that the earth moves around the sun. (Simple Present for universal truths)

**5. After temporal conjunctions:**
❌ I will wait until he will come.
✓ I will wait until he comes. (Present tense after 'until', 'till', 'when', 'before', 'after' in future context)

**Time markers:**
- Since, for → Present Perfect
- Yesterday, ago → Past Simple
- Next, tomorrow → Future
- Always, often, usually → Present Simple

slides.title: Article Errors
slides.content:
Articles (a, an, the) are small but important. Incorrect article usage is a common error.

**Common Article Errors:**

**1. Wrong article:**
❌ He is a honest man.
✓ He is an honest man. (Use 'an' before vowel sound)

❌ She is reading a book in a library.
✓ She is reading a book in the library. (Use 'the' for specific place)

**2. Missing article:**
❌ Sun rises in east.
✓ The sun rises in the east. (Use 'the' with unique objects)

❌ He is student.
✓ He is a student. (Countable singular noun needs article)

**3. Unnecessary article:**
❌ The gold is a precious metal.
✓ Gold is a precious metal. (No article with material nouns in general sense)

❌ The honesty is the best policy.
✓ Honesty is the best policy. (No article with abstract nouns in general sense)

**Remember:**
- Use 'a' before consonant sounds
- Use 'an' before vowel sounds
- Use 'the' for specific/unique things
- No article with plural/uncountable nouns in general sense
- 'The' with superlatives: the best, the tallest
- 'The' with ordinals: the first, the second
- 'The' with unique objects: the sun, the moon, the earth

slides.title: Preposition Errors
slides.content:
Prepositions show relationships between words. Using wrong prepositions is a very common error.

**Common Preposition Errors:**

**1. Wrong preposition:**
❌ He is good in mathematics.
✓ He is good at mathematics.

❌ She is fond with music.
✓ She is fond of music.

❌ I agree with your proposal.
✓ I agree to your proposal. (agree to = consent)

**2. Common confusions:**
- Arrive at (small place) / Arrive in (city/country)
- Different from (not 'different than')
- Composed of (not 'composed with')
- Die of (disease) / Die from (wound)
- Married to (not 'married with')

**3. Time prepositions:**
- On: specific day (on Monday, on 15th August)
- In: month/year/season (in June, in 2023, in summer)
- At: specific time (at 5 PM, at night)

**4. Place prepositions:**
- At: specific point (at the bus stop)
- In: enclosed space (in the room)
- On: surface (on the table)

**Fixed prepositions with adjectives/verbs:**
- Afraid of, angry with/at, good at, interested in
- Depend on, listen to, look at, look for, wait for
- Congratulate on, complain about, apologize for

question.text: He has been living / in this city / since five years / and loves it here. / No Error
question.explanation:
Error is in part (C): 'since five years'

'Since' is used with a point of time (since 2020, since morning).
'For' is used with a period/duration of time (for 5 years, for 2 months).

Correct sentence: He has been living in this city for five years and loves it here.

Remember:
- Since + point of time
- For + period of time

slides.title: Pronoun Errors
slides.content:
Pronouns replace nouns. They must agree with the noun in number, gender, and person.

**Common Pronoun Errors:**

**1. Pronoun-antecedent disagreement:**
❌ Each student must bring their book.
✓ Each student must bring his/her book. ('Each' is singular)

❌ The committee has given their decision.
✓ The committee has given its decision. (Collective noun - singular)

**2. Wrong case:**
❌ Between you and I, this is wrong.
✓ Between you and me, this is wrong. (After preposition, use objective case)

❌ Let he and I go.
✓ Let him and me go. (Objective case after 'let')

**3. Ambiguous reference:**
❌ Ram told Shyam that he had won.
✓ Ram told Shyam that Shyam had won. (or 'Ram had won' - be specific)

**4. Reflexive pronouns:**
❌ He injured him in the accident.
✓ He injured himself in the accident.

**5. Common mistakes:**
- Each other (for two) / One another (for more than two)
- Who (subject) / Whom (object)
- That/Which (things) / Who (people)

**Pronoun cases:**
- Subject: I, he, she, we, they
- Object: me, him, her, us, them
- Possessive: my, his, her, our, their

slides.title: Adjective and Adverb Errors
slides.content:
Adjectives modify nouns; Adverbs modify verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs.

**Common Errors:**

**1. Adjective instead of adverb:**
❌ He drives careful.
✓ He drives carefully. (Adverb to modify verb 'drives')

❌ She spoke very clear.
✓ She spoke very clearly.

**2. Adverb instead of adjective:**
❌ She is differently from her sister.
✓ She is different from her sister. (Adjective after 'is')

**3. Comparative and superlative:**
❌ He is more stronger than me.
✓ He is stronger than me. (Don't use 'more' with '-er')

❌ She is the most prettiest girl.
✓ She is the prettiest girl. (Don't use 'most' with '-est')

❌ Of the two, he is the best.
✓ Of the two, he is the better. (Comparative for two)

**4. Double negatives:**
❌ I didn't do nothing.
✓ I didn't do anything. (or 'I did nothing')

**5. Degree errors:**
- Positive: good, bad, beautiful
- Comparative: better, worse, more beautiful (for two)
- Superlative: best, worst, most beautiful (for three or more)

**Special adjectives:**
- Good/well: I am good (adjective). I play well (adverb).
- Late/Lately: He came late (time). I haven't seen him lately (recently).
- Hard/Hardly: Work hard (with effort). I can hardly see (barely).

slides.title: Common Word Confusions
slides.content:
Some words are commonly confused, leading to errors.

**Commonly Confused Words:**

**1. Its vs It's:**
- Its = possessive (The dog wagged its tail)
- It's = it is (It's a beautiful day)

**2. Affect vs Effect:**
- Affect = verb (The weather affects mood)
- Effect = noun (The effect was immediate)

**3. Their vs There vs They're:**
- Their = possessive (Their house)
- There = place (over there)
- They're = they are (They're coming)

**4. Your vs You're:**
- Your = possessive (Your book)
- You're = you are (You're right)

**5. Then vs Than:**
- Then = time (I will go then)
- Than = comparison (Taller than me)

**6. Lose vs Loose:**
- Lose = verb, to be defeated (Don't lose hope)
- Loose = adjective, not tight (Loose shirt)

**7. Accept vs Except:**
- Accept = to receive (I accept your offer)
- Except = excluding (Everyone except him)

**8. Advise vs Advice:**
- Advise = verb (I advise you to study)
- Advice = noun (Good advice)

**9. Lay vs Lie:**
- Lay = to place (Lay the book on the table) - needs object
- Lie = to recline (I will lie down) - no object

**10. Fewer vs Less:**
- Fewer = countable (Fewer students)
- Less = uncountable (Less water)

question.text: She is more smarter / than her sister / and works / very hard. / No Error
question.explanation:
Error is in part (A): 'She is more smarter'

We should not use 'more' with the comparative form '-er'. It should be either 'more smart' or 'smarter', not both together.

Correct sentence: She is smarter than her sister and works very hard.

Rule: Don't use 'more/most' with '-er/-est' forms:
- Wrong: more better, most biggest
- Correct: better, biggest

slides.title: Strategy for Error Spotting
slides.content:
**Step-by-Step Approach:**

**1. Read the complete sentence first:**
- Understand the meaning
- Identify the tense and context

**2. Check each part systematically:**
- Subject-Verb agreement
- Tense consistency
- Article usage
- Preposition correctness
- Pronoun agreement

**3. Look for common error patterns:**
- Singular/plural mismatch
- Wrong tense form
- Missing/wrong article
- Wrong preposition
- Comparative/superlative errors

**4. If you can't find error:**
- Re-read carefully
- Check if 'No Error' is the answer
- Trust your instinct

**Most Common Errors (Priority Check):**
1. Subject-Verb agreement (30%)
2. Tense errors (20%)
3. Preposition errors (15%)
4. Article errors (15%)
5. Pronoun errors (10%)
6. Adjective/Adverb errors (10%)

**Exam Tips:**
✓ Practice daily with 10-15 questions
✓ Maintain an error diary
✓ Read English newspapers to improve grammar sense
✓ Review grammar rules regularly
✓ Don't spend too much time on one question
✓ If unsure, eliminate obviously correct parts first
